ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Excellent overview over recent works in political theory dealing with the subject of violence.

First and foremost we learned the art of theoretical and philosophical critique, that is the ability to trace and analyze and argument for its merits and demerits. 

Professor Kapustin also modeled for us attention to the subtlety of language and its importance for arguments.

I developed knowledge about the use of violence in societal structure, the difficulty of defining violence because of its physical and mental effects, and ideas about resistance as a means to freedom.

In this class, I learned how to apply critical thinking to philosophical texts, some very dense. Prof Kapustin encourages his students to creatively evaluate the material and is always interested in what we have to say.

This class teaches how to read philosophical texts at more than the surface level. Class discussions are entirely about picking apart and understanding the texts. Enormously helpful for those who think of themselves as good readers -- Boris will show you areas you have to still improve!
The variety of manifestations of political violence and philosophical perspectives on its relationship to reason, law, and history.
A comprehensive understanding of some of the major themes in 20th century political theory, understanding of violence and its origins, better grasp on political philosophical concepts and methods
I learned a great deal about philosophical understandings of violence. While there is some discussion of particular cases, the course drills many of the most notable theoretical analyses of violence.
I learned a ton about theories of violence and power and its role in society and it made me more critically examine the role of violence in society.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: One of the best courses I've taken at Yale. Great seminar quality, and I felt like I learned a lot from Prof. Kapustin and seminar participants alike. However, I will say that this is an upper level seminar so it took me some time to get used to contributing to class (especially as the class was mostly guys.)

I really enjoyed the class discussion and the selection of works, but would have appreciated maybe a shorter final with 2 midterms, so that we could get more personal/in depth feedback and really delve into more of the readings in that setting.
This is a very strong course, there are no substantial structural weaknesses.

Prof Kapustin is the courses main strength. He is extremely insightful and engaging and can get our class discussion out of jams if we are all stuck. The readings were also very interesting and the course topics are well structured.

I love Boris's takes on readings, he is an excellent speaker and always highly engaging. The syllabus is excellent, filled with a mix of classical and unusual texts which really work well together. Sometimes class discussion gets a little quiet when it feels like Boris is looking for one right answer, or when he asks a question that feels like a trick question -- in general, I wish class participation felt a little more low-stakes so that conversations could be more casual.

The syllabus readings are fascinating and in rich conversation with each other. The flexibility of the seminar format is perfect for examining the implications of each reading and potential counterarguments.
No weaknesses, this is overall a tremendous course which encourages student engagement on a deep level.
Strengths are the format of discussions, which include lots of conversation alongside brief lectures by Professor Kapustin on the topics about which we learned.

Strengths: Professor Kapustin is great! He is very excited about teaching and I really enjoyed his class
Weaknesses: I found it very hard to speak in a class that was incredibly male-dominated and it felt like female students rarely got a chance to speak.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It's a normal seminar, but virtual.
This class was run as it would have been if it were live in-person, and as a result there was nothing that would have been better had it been different.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. One of the most intellectually stimulating courses I've taken, with a very insightful professor and high quality of discussion.
Yes, if they are interested in grappling with and consistently engaging with the readings.

Absolutely recommend this course to any student of the social sciences or who is interested in theoretical and philosophical questions of violent and nonviolent political struggle. From Palestines independence struggle, to the Movement for Black Lives in the US, to protests against austerity in Latin America, political struggle is everywhere. This class is a well structured and well taught ideological tour de force of the concept of political violence that will allow any student to be politically astute to past and present global phenomena.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It will completely change the way that you view human nature, morals, power structures. The discussion of the role of historical development in creating modern self-consciousness is particularly fascinating. Readings are complicated but accessible.
Yes, I would recommend this class to anyone interested in philosophy or political science.

Boris is a kind and enthusiastic seminar leader, so I would recommend any course that he teaches. If you've taken classes with Boris before and like his ideas and style, Critique of Political Violence is a solid course on a very specific topic. The readings are largely by 20th-century academic theorists of violence rather than practitioners of violence (no readings by Che, Mao, Lenin, Churchill, Robespierre, etc), so it's definitely a more intellectual take on violence than one might expect. For most students, I would recommend Boris's other seminar Moral Choices in Politics before you take Critique of Political Violence since it has a wider range of content from a more diverse slate of writers.

Absolutely. It's a unique opportunity to examine political violence across a variety of texts that aren't typically found on the same syllabus. It has changed the way I think about history, law, and the moral status of violence in politics.
Absolutely, especially on the merits of Professor Kapustin alone.
I would recommend this course to someone who is interested in the theory behind violence.
It depends on your interests but I feel that I learned a lot in this course!

comments: none
